pullrequest.title: issue #1144 fix inertia ratio reduction error with hardcoded ratio limit. check for violation of line criterion. added test.

content.html:
Is this "abs sum of off diagonals" or "sum of abs off diagonals"?

ie "sum of abs off diagonals" to me means:

for (i=0; i<N; ++i)
  sumAbsOffDiags += abs(offDiagonals[i]);

while "abs sum of off diagonals" means

for (i=0; i<N; ++i)
  sumAbsOffDiags += offDiagonals[i];
sumAbs = abs(sumAbsOffDiags);

Why not actually spell it out:

// To do this, first compute the sum of the absolute values of the off diagonal terms and store in sumAbsOffDiags.

content.raw: The code of this test seems to be the same as the one in TrikeyWheelResponse, except for the world file loaded. I would suggest to keep just a single TrikeyWheelResponse() function with an extra parameter (cons std::string &_worldFile for example). Then, you can just call the same function with the two different world files that the tests are using.
content.html: The code of this test seems to be the same as the one in TrikeyWheelResponse, except for the world file loaded. I would suggest to keep just a single TrikeyWheelResponse() function with an extra parameter (cons std::string &_worldFile for example). Then, you can just call the same function with the two different world files that the tests are using.

content.raw: So it looks like gamma is the ratio between the diagonal `M.d_new` and sum of absolute value of off-diagonal terms `M.od_new`. These equations involve division by zero when `M.od_new = 0`. An alternative is `M.d_new > gamma M.od_new`, with `gamma > 1`.
content.html: So it looks like gamma is the ratio between the diagonal M.d_new and sum of absolute value of off-diagonal terms M.od_new. These equations involve division by zero when M.od_new = 0. An alternative is M.d_new > gamma M.od_new, with gamma > 1.
